text:
Hello Members of this group..

I am working on 3 initiatives..

1. *Hurdles*: Identify the hurdles Ethiopia faces when it comes to sharing information about this virus. 
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vTYq1QseIGMVjHVtaJuksrQnjcwBFesQJ5W7qTCJvQ4/edit?usp=sharing>

*2. Lessons from others:* What did other countries - like Ethiopia - deal with infectious diseases? Right now I am working on Nigeria and Kenya.

<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1_rjGl0-njZFG-2zn1MWO9QmxVTmLHqO3?usp=sharing>

3. *PR Campaign*: A spreadsheet to collect the influencers/groups that have a large following where we can send the graphics that the UX team is working on. All the links are ediatable... please contribute.

<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1f3FmGk1ywa77TEQLFPaBnOUn9RpVV5Zkb_77v34Tul0/edit?usp=sharing>

elements.text:

text:
Impact of religious leaders!
Attending religious services is really meaningful to our community. Religious leaders have a big role to play and think through all the parts of their services and identify all of the schedule when people come in contact either with each other or with a shared common service, and then try to decide whether those moments can either be removed from the service or whether there is another meaningful, comfortable replacement that could stand in for till the virus get under control. So in many houses of worship of all faiths, handshakes should be recommended to replaced with alternatives like waves or elbow bumps. People must advise not to shake hands after prayer, as many commonly do, and leaders have to guid the community of telling  if they are sick, they are exempted from obligations to attend daily,weekly prayers and/or Sunday sermons.

Below CDC Interim guidance to help community and faith based organizations: 

<https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html|https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html>

<https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html|https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html>
<@U010HM8HAQY> <@UVAL943JP> 
#impactofreligiousleaders

Impact of religious leaders!
Attending religious services is really meaningful to our community. Religious leaders have a big role to play and think through all the parts of their services and identify all of the schedule when people come in contact either with each other or with a shared common service, and then try to decide whether those moments can either be removed from the service or whether there is another meaningful, comfortable replacement that could stand in for till the virus get under control. So in many houses of worship of all faiths, handshakes should be recommended to replaced with alternatives like waves or elbow bumps. People must advise not to shake hands after prayer, as many commonly do, and leaders have to guid the community of telling  if they are sick, they are exempted from obligations to attend daily,weekly prayers and/or Sunday sermons.

text:
China and Korea used phone app such as FluPhone that used Bluetooth & other wireless signals proxy for interactions between people and asked users to report flu-like symptoms.
If you’d had lunch with someone who later got sick, FluPhone would let you know. Besides slowing the spread of the flu, the app promised to help health authorities monitor and model the spread of influenza. FluPhone made headlines and the front page of the BBC website at the time. 

<https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/story/phones-track-spread-covid19-good-idea/amp|https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/story/phones-track-spread-covid19-good-idea/amp>

attachments.title: Phones Could Track the Spread of Covid-19. Is It a Good Idea?
attachments.text: China and South Korea used smartphone apps to monitor people with the disease. But Americans have different views of privacy and data collection.
attachments.fallback: Wired: Phones Could Track the Spread of Covid-19. Is It a Good Idea?

elements.text:
China and Korea used phone app such as FluPhone that used Bluetooth & other wireless signals proxy for interactions between people and asked users to report flu-like symptoms.
If you’d had lunch with someone who later got sick, FluPhone would let you know. Besides slowing the spread of the flu, the app promised to help health authorities monitor and model the spread of influenza. FluPhone made headlines and the front page of the BBC website at the time.

text:
Flattering the epidemic, lower peak morbidity and mortality!

Border scale social distancing is likely to be needed, as was put in place in other country. This measure prevents transmission from symptomatic and non-symptomatic cases, hence flattening the epidemic and pushing the peak further into the future. Broader-scale social distancing provides time for the health services to treat cases.
Containment could be targeted to particular areas, schools, or mass gatherings. 
The reduction in transmission, the longer and flatter the epidemic curve with the risk of resurgence when interventions are lifted perhaps to mitigate.

Referring the figure-graph below: baseline simulation with case isolation only (red); a simulation with social distancing in place throughout the epidemic, flattening the curve (green), and a simulation with more effective social distancing in place for a limited period only, typically followed by a resurgent epidemic when social distancing is halted (blue). These are not quantitative predictions but robust qualitative illustrations for a range of model choices. 

The key epidemiological issues that determine the impact of social distancing measures are what proportion of infected individuals have mild symptoms and whether these individuals will self-isolate and to what effectiveness; how quickly symptomatic individuals take to isolate themselves after the onset of symptoms; and the duration of any non-symptomatic infectious period before clear symptoms occur with the linked issue of how transmissible COVID-19 is during this phase.

Individual behaviour will be crucial to control the spread of COVID-19. Personal, rather than government action. 
Early self-isolation, seeking medical advice remotely unless symptoms are severe, and social distancing are key. 
Banning mass gatherings are important, as are good diagnostic facilities and remotely accessed health advice, together with specialised treatment for people with severe disease. How individuals respond to advice on how best to prevent transmission will be as important as government actions, if not more important. 

Government communication strategist, embassies,Immigration officials,airports,religious leaders,Health officials,research institutions,universities,colleges and others gov & ngo orgs have to keep the public informed of how best to avoid infection are vital, as is extra support to manage the the epidemic. 
<@UVAL943JP> <@U010HM8HAQY> 
#Flatteringtheepidemic

elements.text:
Flattering the epidemic, lower peak morbidity and mortality!

Border scale social distancing is likely to be needed, as was put in place in other country. This measure prevents transmission from symptomatic and non-symptomatic cases, hence flattening the epidemic and pushing the peak further into the future. Broader-scale social distancing provides time for the health services to treat cases.
Containment could be targeted to particular areas, schools, or mass gatherings. 
The reduction in transmission, the longer and flatter the epidemic curve with the risk of resurgence when interventions are lifted perhaps to mitigate.

Referring the figure-graph below: baseline simulation with case isolation only (red); a simulation with social distancing in place throughout the epidemic, flattening the curve (green), and a simulation with more effective social distancing in place for a limited period only, typically followed by a resurgent epidemic when social distancing is halted (blue). These are not quantitative predictions but robust qualitative illustrations for a range of model choices. 

The key epidemiological issues that determine the impact of social distancing measures are what proportion of infected individuals have mild symptoms and whether these individuals will self-isolate and to what effectiveness; how quickly symptomatic individuals take to isolate themselves after the onset of symptoms; and the duration of any non-symptomatic infectious period before clear symptoms occur with the linked issue of how transmissible COVID-19 is during this phase.

Individual behaviour will be crucial to control the spread of COVID-19. Personal, rather than government action. 
Early self-isolation, seeking medical advice remotely unless symptoms are severe, and social distancing are key. 
Banning mass gatherings are important, as are good diagnostic facilities and remotely accessed health advice, together with specialised treatment for people with severe disease. How individuals respond to advice on how best to prevent transmission will be as important as government actions, if not more important. 

Government communication strategist, embassies,Immigration officials,airports,religious leaders,Health officials,research institutions,universities,colleges and others gov & ngo orgs have to keep the public informed of how best to avoid infection are vital, as is extra support to manage the the epidemic.
